subject: Medicine
title: Henrietta Lacks and Cell Rights
description: Learn Henrietta Lacks and Cell Rights in one minute.

hook.text: Henrietta Lacks died in 1951. Her cells are still alive todayâ€”used in research without her family's knowledge.

buildup.text: HeLa cells, taken from Henrietta's tumor, became the most important cell line in medical research history.

discovery.text: They helped develop the polio vaccine, cancer treatments, and HIV drugsâ€”generating billions in commercial value.

twist.text: Her family was never told, never consented, and never compensatedâ€”while companies profited from her cells.

climax.text: Her story forced a reckoning about who owns human tissue and who benefits from medical discoveries.

punchline.text: Her cells saved millions. Nobody asked her.

quiz.question: What ethical issue did Henrietta Lacks's story highlight?
options: Patients' tissue was used without consent or compensation
Medical research should never use human cells
